DOC.HEAD: Precede: MANILA
French Missionary, Niece Kidnapped in Southern Philippines
Eds: UPDATES with new details, CORRECTS place of kidnapping and identity of previous kidnappers
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen believed to be Moslem bandits kidnapped a French missionary and his niece in the southern Philippines, and police killed one of the abductors in a firefight, police and church officials said Sunday. The Rev. Michel de Gigord and his 29-year-old niece, Benedict, were abducted Saturday after leaving Saint Mary's Convent in Marawi, 510 miles southeast of Manila. said the Rev. Leo Laviste, Vicar General of Archdiocese of Iligan and Marawi cities. Laviste said they have not yet heard from the kidnappers. Laviste said de Gigord, was driving his niece toward Iligan City, 20 miles to the north, when six armed men stopped their car near the convent's gate. One of the gunmen shoved de Gigord from the driver's seat and, followed by a jeep boarded by the other kidnappers, drove the priest's car to the shores of nearby Lanao Lake and sent the two victims by boat to an island in the lake, Laviste said. Neighbors who saw the abduction immediately informed authorities in the convent who notified the local police. Pursuing policemen engaged in a gunbattle with some of the gunmen who had been left behind on the lakeshore, killing one of them, Marawi police station commander Capt. Jalandoni Cota. He said the others escaped. Police also recovered de Gigord's vehicle, abandoned by the kidnappers. There was no report on what happened to the kidnapper's jeep. Sources at the Lanao del Sur provincial military and police headquarters said the victims have been moved by the kidnappers to the town of Madamba, 23 miles west of Marawi, late Sunday morning. Provincial commander Lt. Col. Omar Manabilang has sought the assistance of the mayors of Madamba and two adjacent towns and local Moslem religious leaders to help rescue the priest and his niece, the sources said. De Gigord, a member of the Paris Foreign Mission, has been chaplain at the Mindanao State University in Marawi for the past 10 years. He was kidnapped by Moslem bandits in February 1985 and held captive for about a month in their mountain hideout but was released unharmed.
